title: DS330.23 Projecting Traversals | DataStax Enterprise 6 Graph
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS330
DS330.23 Projecting Traversals
In this unit, you will learn about projecting traversals. A projecting traversal are those steps which use previously labeled traversals in your query and bring them forward to be used again. Projecting traversals generate new traversals that correspond to the previously labeled steps.

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] hey everyone i'm denise gosnell and this is projecting traversals when we are building gremlin queries i like to think of this process loosely in my head as the reverse of the traditional select from where to me projecting traversals are a way that you can wear from and select it gives you the ability to do those select statements and pick the data you want to see at that point in your query so a bit more concretely a projecting traversal are those steps which use your previously labeled traversers in your query and bring them forward to be used again projecting traversals generate new traversers that correspond to the previously labeled steps a projecting traversal can also be simple branching recursive path and so on so let's visualize this in this diagram we can see six total states for our traversers a start a finish and four traversal states in between the small colored triangles above the gremlins at the start and step three represent labeled steps we can imagine that the step at the finish was a projecting step which specifically asked to bring forward the traversers from the start and step 3. we see this as the marked gremlins are visually duplicated and brought forward to the right after the finishing step in the gremlin language we have two examples of projecting traversals the most common one we use is the select step the select step is used to grab a previously labeled traversal to make use of it later on its parameters are step labels that are previously defined in the query using the step modulator as the next step to talk about is where there are multiple ways to use the step where in the gremlin language but the use that is most like a projecting step is when we use where to recall a previous step and evaluate some predicate on those traversers where does not return or project new traversers but instead it can refer to previously labeled steps to evaluate some condition we are going to use both select and where in some examples coming up and the difference between them will be much more clear there are two step modulators that are frequently used with projecting traversals as and by the as step is the way to label a part of your gremlin query this is the must-have step with a projecting traversal we have to label something with as in order to use it again later in the query in practice we use the as step to assign a meaningful name to a part of a traversal then that can be used later on buy is also very useful to use with projecting traversals it is similar to saying that we now have some object and we want to use it in a particular way the bi-step modulator is frequently used in projecting traversals to specify what to project such as a specific element property value id or even another internal traversal as a result both the as and by step modulators are not specific to projecting traversals and they can be used with many other steps in other traversals but we're going to walk through some examples that show how to use them for projecting traversals as a reminder as always this is our killer video graph schema movies are related to people movies belong to genres there are people who have acted directed composed and other types of activities with the movies users rate movies and users know other users so let's dig in and go through an example let's say for an example that we want to find the movies that johnny depp has acted in and we want to create a specific payload that has the keys actor and movie to do that remember that we're loosely going in reverse from traditional querying here we want to follow the loose traversal pattern of where from and then select to do this we start by finding where our gremlin traverser is going to start their journey the johnny depp person vertex and that's the first query you see once we found where we are starting let's give this step a name by using the as step here we're labeling the johnnydepp person vertex as actor from our starting point we need to get to the movie vertices by walking through the edge pointing into the actor vertex let's label this step as movie lastly we want to select some data to be returned from our query specifically we want to select the actor johnny depp and the movies he has acted in and we want to build up a view of that data so we use the buy modulators you will need to write as many by modulators as items you are selecting the first bimodulator is going to apply to the first item that you're selecting so as you can see here we want to select the actor vertex by their name next the second bimodulator is going to apply to the second object that we're selecting in the select step which is the movie we can select any property from the movie vertex in the bimodulator but here we just wanted to look at the movie's title and finally let's take a look at one of the results and you can see here that we have the key actor with the value johnny depp and the key movie with alice in wonderland in this next example maybe our application needs more than just the actor's name and the movie title so in this example we're going to add in the year and the genre to do that remember that we're loosely going in reverse from traditional querying here we want to follow that general traversal pattern of where from and then select let's start with the where we need to identify where our traversers are going to start and where they're going to then walk through the graph as before we query for the johnnydepp person vertex and label it a with the as step from this starting point we need to walk to movies and genres to get access to the remaining three elements for our payload we walk through the in-edge actor to get to the movie vertices we know the movie vertices have the title and year for the film so we give these vertices two labels t for title and y for year from the movie vertices we walk over to the genre vertices using the belongs to edge let's label this with a g for genre lastly we need to use the projecting step select to access our label data remember for each item we select we also need to provide a bimodulator to indicate exactly which piece of data we want to put into our payload so as you see here the a was for actor and we want to select the actor by their name t and y were on the movie vertices so we want to select the title and the year lastly for g the genre we want to select the genre's name let's sample two of those and take a look at the data you can see we found johnny depp from the movie into the woods which was labeled as a comedy from 2014 and it was also labeled as a fantasy from 2014. one last example of the where from select pattern in this final example of a projecting traversal we're going to again find johnny depp's movies with their title and year but this time we're going to add in calculating their average ratings so we're going to start off as we did before we're going to find the johnny depp person vertex and label it with an a for actor next we're going to go to the movies johnny depp's movies and we're going to label that set of vertices with t y and r for title year and rating this time we're going to select the actors and the movie vertices but we're going to add in a traversal in the bimodulator the first three bi-modulators are the same as before we're selecting the actor by their name the movie by its title and then the movie again by its year and lastly we need to find the ratings or the average ratings for each of these movies and for that bi modulator we're going to do a traversal from the movie vertex we need to go through the edge rated which is an in edge and on that edge we need to get access to the rating values by saying values rating and then we would like to compute the mean we're going to sample one and take a look at the results we find johnny depp alice in wonderland from the year 2010 with an average rating of six from our users in killer video the last three examples have demonstrated how we use as select and buy in projecting traversals next let's bring the step where into our query as a filter in this example we want to find directors who appeared in their own movies in this traversal we want to start with our person vertices but we only want to start with those people who both directed and acted in the same movie now this query is going to have to be run in olap mode because it requires analyzing a full partition of vertices namely the person vertices regardless to do this we want to start by labeling all person vertices as d which will eventually be used for director but starting from here we have all persons not just directors so with this data model we have to walk out to the movie vertex through the director edge to filter out all persons who are not directors we eventually will need data from the movie vertex so while we're here let's label this step with t and y as before since we know we're going to need the title and year from the movie vertex later on next we will walk back to the person vertices through the actor edge and label these traversers as a for actor now here's the trick we want to select the persons from the first step and only select those traversers who are labeled d and only let those traversers live on if their corresponding actor is the same we do this by selecting d and apply a filter with the where statement specifically we allow all d persons to pass our filter only if they are the same person as the actor a in other words if we have a director who is also an actor in the movie we would like those traversers to pass through this filter the next select builds up the payload we want with the remaining values from the traversal the directors movie title and the year of the movie and hopefully this was one of the examples you imagine that you would come up with quentin tarantino from pulp fiction in 1994. let's do one last example here to show you yet another way to use the select where pattern we're going to stick with the same concept we want to find the directors who appeared in their own movies but this time let's make use of a different form of the where pattern the query is the exact same as before with only one change we eliminate the first select and only use where and the second select this is possible with the additional parameter for where that specifies the labeled step d both solutions are semantically equivalent it's just a matter of which syntax seems more readable to you projecting traversals are one of our most important tools in our gremlin toolbox it gives you the ability to really understand how to walk through your data and pick out that exact piece of data that you're looking for now it's your turn to give it a try give this next exercise a go and get your hands dirty with projecting traversals
